qas.question: Which adaptation helps both predators and prey?
What term is used for an adaptation that enables species to blend into the background?
Camoflauge consists of what else, in addition to color?
Ogranisms use camoflauge to blend with their habitat and what else?
What characteristic helps only prey not be seen?
What else can be used to describe dead leaves besides their color?
What is it a form of when lions can see a single zebra?
What does a praying mantis use to build its home?
What method does a praying mantis use when hunting?

context: One adaptation helping both predators and prey avoid detection is <a0_0><a1_0><b4_0>camouflage<b4_0/><a1_0/><a0_0/>, a form of <b6_0>crypsis<b6_0/> where species have an appearance that helps them blend into the background. Camouflage consists of not only color but also <a2_0><b5_0>shape and pattern<b5_0/><a2_0/>. The background upon which the organism is seen can be both its environment (e.g., the praying mantis to the right resembling <b7_0>dead leaves<b7_0/>) or <a3_0>other organisms<a3_0/> (e.g., zebras' stripes blend in with each other in a herd, making it difficult for lions to <b8_0>focus on a single target<b8_0/>). The more convincing camouflage is, the more likely it is that the organism will go unseen.
